symbol_sets.description: Clean Japanese syllabary; monospaced, structured, and ideal for pattern recognition.
Visually rich and distinct; great for attention-grabbing patterns but may distract in complex logic.
Ancient Germanic script with geometric clarity; excellent for mirroring, tiling, and symmetry tasks.
Structured characters used for drawing boxes; ideal for spatial transformations like rotation or reflection.
Directional glyphs that imply motion or transformation direction; useful for physics-based puzzles.
Abstract logic symbols; ideal for formal rule learning but may confuse small models.
Pictographic ancient script; helps classify object types and semantic groupings.
Represents values as dice faces; good for state-based logic but risks numeric interpretation.
Tactile writing system; great for spatial orientation and physical logic puzzles.
Ancient Greek-like script; excellent for syllabic pattern detection.
Used in Mycenaean Greece; pictographic and abstract.
Predecessor of Cyrillic script; highly structured and historical.
Mormon script for English reform; clean and geometric.
Etruscan/Oscan roots; simple shapes, left-to-right logic.
Used in liturgy; still used today, supports clear structure.
Obscure Anatolian script; rarely seen in training data.
Early Mesopotamian script; wedge-shaped, structured layout.
Pre-Islamic Semitic script; RTL-aware, good for symmetry.
Elvish script from Tolkien's world; logical glyph structure.
Tactile writing for blind users; simulated with text blocks.
Earliest known alphabetic script; rare and pictographic.
Cuneiform-based alphabet; extinct but visually varied.
Inspired by Mayan hieroglyphs; object-like meaning aids classification.
Ancient cuneiform variant; structured and logical.
High contrast, unique baseline; good for shape variation.
Syllabic African script; strong structural diversity.
Native American writing system; syllabic and balanced.
Berber script; RTL-aware and structurally rich.
Irish tree alphabet; vertical lines help with symmetry tasks.
Extinct Germanic language; unique glyphs force abstraction.
Early Chinese symbols; proto-writing system with abstract logic.
First true alphabet; minimalistic, high contrast.
Undeciphered script; perfect for forcing pure pattern inference.
Inspired by Aztec/Mexica gylphs; object-like symbols aid grouping.
Classical Greek alphabet; good for logic and repetition.
RTL-aware script; excellent for testing symmetry and mirror logic.
Runic variants with directional cues; helps with flip/mirror reasoning.
Decorative glyphs; good for visual separation and pattern matching.
Chess piece notation; helps detect movement and swapping.
Card symbols; good for classification and state change.
Formal logic operators; good for parity and binary transformations.
Symbolic representation of rhythm; great for repetition and sequence logic.
Historical alchemy symbols; good for mapping abstract concepts.
Celestial symbols; useful for orbit-style movement or rotation puzzles.
Weather-based emoji; helps infer state changes over time.
Money-related glyphs; good for classification and value shift puzzles.
Maya numeral system; dot/bar based, good for state logic.
Runic meanings added for logic; e.g., ᚠ = wealth, ᛉ = defense, etc.
Basic geometric forms; great for rotation, symmetry, and spatial logic.
Alchemical elements mapped to colors; good for classification puzzles.
Astrological glyphs; good for symbolic logic and rotation patterns.
Directional indicators; useful for flow, pathfinding, or trajectory puzzles.
Simulates Maya calendar glyphs; great for cyclic or repeating logic.
Tarot card symbols; good for abstract state transitions.
Braille patterns; tactile logic helps with spatial transformations.
Egyptian number glyphs; pictographic logic improves pattern recognition.
Constructed alphabet for English; unfamiliar but consistent logic.
Vertical Irish script; symmetry aids mirror detection.
Domino tile representations; state-based logic works well for swapping rules.
Simple pictographic symbols; good for object-based classification.
Old Futhark runes with directional overlays; helps combine motion + mirroring.
Common objects represented by emoji; good for grouping and labeling.
Chinese radicals; pictographic, helps with object-based puzzles.
Cypro-Minoan script; rare and pictographic, good for pattern-only learning.
Direction-based ideograms; helps detect gravity or trajectory logic.
Old Slavic letters; structured and culturally neutral.
Elvish script with directional logic; good for advanced pattern learning.
Aztec pictographic logic; excellent for object classification and grouping.
Basic Kanji radicals; monospace-friendly, no numeric bias.
Extended Roman numerals with alternate glyphs; good for basic transformations.
Symbols represent stroke order; excellent for sequential logic.
Runic script with gravity cues; combines movement and mirroring logic.
Khipu-inspired strings; non-grid-based logic, great for unconventional puzzles.
Undeciphered script; forces pure pattern recognition.
Braille cells with directional clues; good for spatial reasoning.
Wedge-shaped symbols; good for structured pattern inference.
Emoji with facial expressions; helps track object identity through transformation.
Futhark runes; use different ones for swap logic.
Anatolian logograms; pictographic and rare in training data.
Animal signs; helps with classification and object tracking.
Early Hebrew script; RTL-aware and visually varied.
Unicode arrow variants; ideal for movement and physics puzzles.
Undeciphered Aegean script; forces pure visual inference.
Armenian script; unique baseline and structure.
Indus seals with animal figures; great for classification.
Country flags; good for classification and label-based logic.
Five elements and their variations; good for thematic transformations.
Vertical Irish script; forces structural reading of grids.
Weather-based emoji; good for dynamic state-change puzzles.
Mathematical operators; good for formal logic and transformation rules.
Transport-related emoji; great for movement-based puzzles.
Mirror-symmetric runic variants; great for detecting flips.
Repetition-focused radicals; helps detect mirrored logic.
Runic glyphs with downward emphasis; good for gravity puzzles.
Radicals that suggest movement or change; good for dynamic puzzles.
Mathematical Alphanumeric Symbols; formal style for logic-based transformations.
Nature-themed emoji; good for object classification and tracking.
Runes with implied flow direction; helps with movement and gravity.
Domino pairs with dot combinations; good for state-based logic.
Mayan dot/bar numerals; good for base-change or state puzzles.
Runes selected for symmetry; great for mirror and reflection logic.
Classify using Chinese radicals; object-based reasoning.
Ogham with directional cues; helps infer motion and flipping.
Weather icons as symbolic states; good for state-based puzzles.
